spans.content: C106B Discussion 1: Dynamical Systems & Linear Control
1.1 Where will discussions fit in to 106B?
Discussions in 106B will primarily be to reinforce your understanding of concepts from lecture with
practice problems. In some weeks, we’ll introduce some new foundational material in discussion so the
following lectures can cover active areas of research in those subjects. Discussions will always be recorded
1.2 What content will we cover in this class?
In this class, we’ll cover topics ranging from nonlinear control to path planning, vision, and optimal
control and reinforcement learning (RL). As we get into more advanced topics, we’ll provide you with
the tools you need to get started in topics such as analysis, probability, and machine learning - we’ll only
In this class, no student should feel left behind! Please ask us or any of your classmates if you have any
questions at all! We want to make this course a wonderful learning experience for all of you.
Nonlinear systems of differential equations come in all shapes and sizes! When trying to perform general
analysis of these systems, this can be challenging! Is there some convention we can use to treat general
In general, we say that any (time invariant) nonlinear system may be described by the following equations:

\begin{array}{r l r}&{\dot{x}=f(x,u),\ x\in\mathbb{R}^{n},u\in\mathbb{R}^{m}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad}&{\ S t a t e\ E q u a t i o n}\\ &{y=h(x,u)\ y\in\mathbb{R}^{p}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad}&{\ O u t p u t\ E q u a t i o n}\end{array}
This description of a system is called state space. What are the different components?
: State vector, contains smallest set of variables needed to completely describe system configura-
: Input vector, contains variables we have total control over
: Output vector, commonly contains variables we are interested in controlling or those we measure
transform it into a system of
first order equations using phase variables.

\begin{array}{r l r}&{\dot{x}=f(x,u),\ x\in\mathbb{R}^{n},u\in\mathbb{R}^{m}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad}&{\ S t a t e\ E q u a t i o n}\\ &{y=h(x,u)\ y\in\mathbb{R}^{p}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad}&{\ O u t p u t\ E q u a t i o n}\end{array}

An equilibrium point of a system
At an equilibrium point, the evolution of the system is “frozen.” Notice that the zero vector
Let’s think of a rough definition of what it means for an equilibrium point to be stable. If we start at
close to an equilibrium point and remain close for all time, the equilibrium point
is stable. Otherwise, the equilibrium point is unstable.

We previously saw that the stability of the origin of a linear system is linked to the eigenvalues of the
. Can we use this knowledge to stabilize unstable linear systems?
Suppose we have a linear system, this time with a scalar input
has a real component greater than zero, this system will be naturally unstable if
we don’t provide the system with some control input. Let’s try the input:
Using this input, we can move the eigenvalues of many linear systems to stable locations! This is a form
of feedback control known as state feedback. Note that state feedback also extends to the multi-input
